articles.headline: Puerto Rico Is Once Again Hit by an Islandwide Blackout
articles.snippet: The major failure, nearly seven months after Hurricane Maria ravaged Puerto Rico, could take up to 36 hours to fix.
articles.abstract: The major failure, nearly seven months after Hurricane Maria ravaged Puerto Rico, could take up to 36 hours to fix.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — After seven months and close to $2.5 billion, almost everybody in hurricane-ravaged Puerto Rico had their lights back on — until a freak accident on Wednesday plunged the entire island once again into darkness.
articles.byline: By James Wagner and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Raúl Castro Prepares to Resign as Cuba’s President, Closing a Dynasty
articles.snippet: Without the Castro legacy to rely on, his successor will face a minefield of tasks that even Mr. Castro failed to complete.
articles.abstract: Without the Castro legacy to rely on, his successor will face a minefield of tasks that even Mr. Castro failed to complete.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Raúl Castro, who took over from his brother Fidel 12 years ago and led Cuba through some of its biggest changes in decades, is expected to step down on Thursday and hand power to someone outside the Castro dynasty for the first time since the Cuban revolution more than half a century ago.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Current Status With Advertisers? It’s Complicated
articles.snippet: Marketers have long had a symbiotic relationship with the social network. But user concerns about data has companies taking a harder look at how they work with Facebook.
articles.abstract: Marketers have long had a symbiotic relationship with the social network. But user concerns about data has companies taking a harder look at how they work with Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Advertisers are the lifeblood of Facebook, and the vast, personal reach of the social network has been a marketer’s dream. But now, some companies are taking a harder look at how they work with it and hunting for skeletons in their own data closets.

articles.headline: Inside Southwest Flight 1380, 20 Minutes of Chaos and Terror
articles.snippet: “Dear Jesus, send some angels.” Passengers feared they would die as an engine exploded, plunging the plane thousands of feet in a minute.
articles.abstract: “Dear Jesus, send some angels.” Passengers feared they would die as an engine exploded, plunging the plane thousands of feet in a minute.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of feet above the earth, the passengers clasped hands with strangers, prayed together and got ready to die.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Across Midwest, Farmers Warn of G.O.P. Losses Over Trump’s Trade Policy
articles.snippet: China’s proposed tariffs on soybeans would hit hard in Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, North Dakota and other states with highly competitive House and Senate races.
articles.abstract: China’s proposed tariffs on soybeans would hit hard in Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, North Dakota and other states with highly competitive House and Senate races.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASSELTON, N.D. — Here in the largest soybean-producing county in the country, a snowy winter has left North Dakota farmers like Robert Runck with time on their hands before spring planting — time they have spent stewing over how much they stand to lose if President Trump starts a trade war with China.

articles.headline: Harper’s Editor Insists He Was Fired Over Katie Roiphe Essay
articles.snippet: The essay stirred controversy on Twitter. It was also the subject of debate at the venerable monthly. Now the editor, James Marcus, is out.
articles.abstract: The essay stirred controversy on Twitter. It was also the subject of debate at the venerable monthly. Now the editor, James Marcus, is out.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Marcus wants the world to know that he was fired from his job as the editor of Harper’s Magazine. He is not stepping down voluntarily to work on a book, which he said was the face-saving “official narrative” offered to him by John R. MacArthur, the magazine’s longtime president and publisher. He also said that he had refused to accept a severance payment that was contingent on his signing a non-disparagement agreement.

articles.headline: Tech’s Hollywood Takeover: Amazon Reboots ‘Citizen Kane’ and ‘E.T.’ Studio
articles.snippet: The tech giant has moved its entertainment division into Culver Studios, a 14-acre site where “Gone With the Wind” was also filmed.
articles.abstract: The tech giant has moved its entertainment division into Culver Studios, a 14-acre site where “Gone With the Wind” was also filmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — It was as if they were stepping into 1940, the heart of Hollywood’s golden age.

articles.headline: Can Training Eliminate Biases? Starbucks Will Test the Thesis
articles.snippet: Some researchers say training can help alleviated biased treatment, but others warn that it can be ineffective or even backfire.
articles.abstract: Some researchers say training can help alleviated biased treatment, but others warn that it can be ineffective or even backfire.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday, reeling from an incident at a Starbucks in Philadelphia that prompted accusations of racial bias, Howard Schultz, the company’s executive chairman, called the head of a nonprofit public-policy organization to discuss ways to prevent similar episodes in the future.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: A Marriage Used to Prevent Deportation. Not Anymore.
articles.snippet: For decades, marriage to a United States citizen has been a virtual guarantee of legal residency. It isn’t anymore under the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: For decades, marriage to a United States citizen has been a virtual guarantee of legal residency. It isn’t anymore under the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: They had shown the immigration officer their proof — the eight years of Facebook photos, their 5-year-old son’s birth certificate, the letters from relatives and friends affirming their commitment — and now they were so close, Karah de Oliveira thought, so nearly a normal couple.

articles.headline: Trump Wants to Close Trade Gap, but Leaves Export Agency in Limbo
articles.snippet: The Export-Import Bank has been effectively crippled, and big business groups are angry that the board of the bank has been left completely vacant.
articles.abstract: The Export-Import Bank has been effectively crippled, and big business groups are angry that the board of the bank has been left completely vacant.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As trade tensions mount, an 84-year-old Washington institution could have been a powerful tool for President Trump. The institution, the Export-Import Bank, was created to help American companies compete overseas and bolster exports by providing cheap government-backed loans.

articles.headline: North Korea Drops Troop Demand, but U.S. Reacts Warily
articles.snippet: North Korea’s leader will no longer demand that American troops leave South Korea, the South’s president said, but American officials dismissed the idea that it was a capitulation.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s leader will no longer demand that American troops leave South Korea, the South’s president said, but American officials dismissed the idea that it was a capitulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea has dropped its demand that American troops be removed from South Korea as a condition for giving up its nuclear weapons, South Korea’s president said Thursday in presenting the idea to the United States.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Who Is Miguel Díaz-Canel, Cuba’s New President?
articles.snippet: Most expect Cuba’s new president to be a leader of continuity after Raúl Castro. But he also has to figure out how to resuscitate Cuba’s economy.
articles.abstract: Most expect Cuba’s new president to be a leader of continuity after Raúl Castro. But he also has to figure out how to resuscitate Cuba’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA  — As soon as Cuba and the Obama administration decided to restore diplomatic relations, decades of bitter stagnation began to give way. Embassies were being reopened. Americans streamed to the island. The curtain was suddenly pulled back from Cuba, a nation frozen out by the Cold War.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Frances Robles
